did.abstract: The collection contains materials documenting Sayre Sheldon's involvement in international women's rights, peace, and nuclear disarmament movements. A significant amount pertains to Women's Action for New Directions, and a smaller amount to Dr. Helen Caldicott.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for use without restriction beyond the standard terms and conditions of Smith College Special Collections. Collection is stored offsite; researchers must give 48 hours advance notice. Collection has not been fully processed and therefore may be somewhat difficult to use. Original AV materials may not be used; in-house use copies must be made for researchers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The collection was gifted by Sayre Sheldon in 2009 and 2015.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p: Sayre Sheldon was born in Boston, Mass. on September 28, 1926, the daughter of Ruth Wilma Schoellkopf and Philip Phillips. She graduated from Putney School in 1944, and went on to earn her B.S from Radcliffe College in 1948, and her M.A. in American Literature from Boston University in 1956. Sheldon has been a long time political and social activist. She was co-founder of Women's Action for New Directions (originally Women's Party for Survival, then Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament) with Dr. Helen Caldicott, and President Emerita of the National WAND Board. She is professor of literature at Boston University and has been involved in that university's Metropolitan College prison program. She has authored several plays and articles about women's issues and peace issues. She edited the anthology Her War Story: 20th Century Women Write About War, published in 1999 by Southern Illinois University Press. Sheldon represents WAND as an NGO at the United Nations.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: To the extent that she owns copyright, Sheldon has assigned the copyright in her works to Smith College; however, copyright in other items in this collection may be held by their respective creators. For reproductions of materials that are governed by fair use as defined under U. S. Copyright Law, no permission to cite or publish is required. For instances which may regard materials in the collection not created by Sheldon, researchers are responsible for determining who may hold materials' copyrights and obtaining approval from them. Researchers do not need anything further from Smith College Special Collections to move forward with their use.
